facts.text: Civil Appeal No.18 of 1955 arises from judgment and decree dated March 20, 1951, of Mysore High Court in R.A. No. 155 of 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.18 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 20, 1651, of the Mysore High Court in R.A. No. 155 of 1947-48, arising out of the judgment and decree dated December 19, 1947, of the Court of SubJudge, Mysore, in 0. S. Suit No. 44 of 1946-47.

facts.text: Original suit O.S. Suit No. 44 of 1946-47 filed in Court of SubJudge, Mysore, judgment and decree dated December 19, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No.18 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 20, 1651, of the Mysore High Court in R.A. No. 155 of 1947-48, arising out of the judgment and decree dated December 19, 1947, of the Court of SubJudge, Mysore, in 0. S. Suit No. 44 of 1946-47.

facts.text: Appellant brought suit as sole executor of will executed by Lakshmamma on August 22, 1945, Ex. A.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-This appeal arises from a suit brought by the appellant in the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge, Mysore, as the sole executor of the will alleged to have been executed by one Lakshmamma on August 22, 1945,  Ex. A . In this suit the appellant claimed a declaration that the said Lakshmamma was the owner of the properties mentioned in the schedule attached to the plaint and as such was entitled to dispose of them by a will and be asked for companysequential reliefs purporting to give effect to the bequests made by the said will.

facts.text: Lakshmamma died on September 26, 1945, at Mandya.

anchor.surface_text: One Annaji lyengar who died in July 1903 left behind him his adopted son, the appellant, and two daughters Gundamma alias Ranganayakamma who is still alive and Lakshmamma alias Achamma who is alleged to have executed the will in suit and died thereafter on September 26, 1945, at Mandya.

facts.text: Annaji Iyengar died in July 1903.

anchor.surface_text: Before referring to the pleadings of the parties it would be relevant to mention the material facts in regard to their relationship which are number in dispute. One Annaji lyengar who died in July 1903 left behind him his adopted son, the appellant, and two daughters Gundamma alias Ranganayakamma who is still alive and Lakshmamma alias Achamma who is alleged to have executed the will in suit and died thereafter on September 26, 1945, at Mandya.

facts.text: Annaji Iyengar made gift of items 1 and 2 to Lakshmamma and Sadagopalachar under registered deed Ex. D on February 16, 1902.

anchor.surface_text: According to the case set out by the appellant in his plaint Annaji lyengar bad made a gift of properties, items 1 and 2, in favour jointly of Lakshmamma and Sadagopalachar under a registered deed of gift on February 16, 1902  Ex. D .

facts.text: Annaji Iyengar executed will Ex. B2 on August 31, 1901, bequeathing hypothecation bonds Rs. 10,320 to Lakshmamma and Sadagopalachar with survivorship.

anchor.surface_text: It was also alleged that the said Annaji lyengar had executed a will On August 31, 1901,  Ex. B2 a   under which he had bequeathed in favour of Lakshmamma and Sadagopalachar hypo- thecation bonds to the extent of Rs. 10,320 as gift with the express stipulation that the survivor of the legatees should take the whole of the bequest by survivorship.

facts.text: Sadagopalachar died in December 1908.

anchor.surface_text: Lakshmamma was married to Sadagopalachar who died in December 1908.

facts.text: Narayana Iyengar, son of Lakshmamma, died on January 14, 1944, without issue, leaving widow respondent 1.

anchor.surface_text: The companyple had three children, a son named Narayana lyengar who died on January 14, 1944, without any issue and left behind him his widow respondent 1 and the two remaining children of Lakshmamma were daughters Thirumalamma and Yadugiramma.

facts.text: Trial court (SubJudge) held Lakshmamma had half share in all properties, will Ex. A genuine for that share, decreed possession of half in items 3,4,5, Rs.1050 mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, according to the learned judge, Lakshmamma had a half share in all the properties in suit and so she was companypetent to make the will in respect of the said share. The learned judge then companysidered the question as to the execution of the will set up by the appellant and came to the companyclusion that the will  Ex. A  was genuine and valid to the extent of the share belonging to the testatrix.

facts.text: Mysore High Court held will not proved, as Lakshmamma not in sound disposing state, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the appellant had number established that when Lakshmamma was alleged to have executed the will she was in a sound and disposing state of mind or that it was her will in the sense that it represented her intentions.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered November 13, 1958 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. November 13. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-This appeal arises from a suit brought by the appellant in the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge, Mysore, as the sole executor of the will alleged to have been executed by one Lakshmamma on August 22, 1945,  Ex. A .

facts.text: Properties in schedule: items 1-3 agricultural lands at Hampapura (5,4,4), item 4: 9 lands at Arjunahalli, item 5: vacant site Hampapura.

anchor.surface_text: In this suit the appellant claimed a declaration that the said Lakshmamma was the owner of the properties mentioned in the schedule attached to the plaint and as such was entitled to dispose of them by a will and be asked for companysequential reliefs purporting to give effect to the bequests made by the said will. The schedule attached to the plaint describes the properties companyered by the will under five items.

facts.text: Under will, respondent 1 entitled to life interest in items 1 and 2, then to respondents 2-4 and 5.

anchor.surface_text: First three items in the schedule refer respectively to 5, 4 and 4 agricultural lands at Hampapura village, whereas the fourth item includes 9 lands at Arjunahalli village and the last item is. vacant site in Hampapura village. According to the plaint, under the will respondent I was entitled only to a life interest in items I and 2 and that on her death the said items would vest in respondents 2 to 4 and respondent 5 respectively.

facts.text: Appellant claimed possession against respondent 1 for items 3,4,5, life interest declaration for 1,2, Rs.2106 past income, mesne profits.

anchor.surface_text: Since respondent 1 was in possession of all the five items, the appellant claimed a decree for possession against respondent 1 in respect of items 3, 4 and 5 and a declaration that respondent I was to have only a life interest in items 1 and 2. By his plaint the appellant also claimed to recover Rs. 2,106 which had been companylected by respondent 1 by way of income from the suit lands and a further prayer was made for the payment of current mesne profits by respondent 1.

facts.text: Sadagopalachar used Rs.10,320 from Annaji's will to buy immovable properties including items 3 and 4.

anchor.surface_text: During the companyrse of the management Sadagopalachar used the cash of Rs. 10,320 received by bequest under the will of Annaji lyengar to buy some immoveable properties including items 3 and 4.

facts.text: Respondent 1 denied Annaji's will Ex.B2, denied survivorship in gift deed Ex.D, claimed Lakshmamma transferred interest to Sadagopalachar.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent I disputed the appellants claim. She denied that Annaji lyengar had made a will on August 31, 1901, or that Lakshmamma and Sadagopalachar had received the moveables of the value of Rs. 10,320 under it. According to her, the gift deed  Ex. D  did number provide for devolution of interest by survivorship she pleaded that Lakshmamma had transferred all her interests in the properties companyprised in the gift deed in favour of her husband Sadagopalachar who then became their sole owner.

facts.text: Trial judge found Annaji's will genuine, survivorship for will properties, no survivorship for gift deed, Lakshmamma half share.

anchor.surface_text: On these pleadings the learned trial judge framed fifteen issues. He found that the will executed by Annaji lyengar on August 31, 1901, was genuine and valid and that the rule of survivorship was applicable as between the legatees inter se in respect of the properties companyveyed by the said will. It was, however, held that the rule of survivorship did Dot apply to the properties gifted to Sadagopalachar and Lakshmamma under Annajis deed of gift  Ex. D  which was held to be genuine and valid.

facts.text: High Court held appellant failed to prove source of funds for items 3,4,5 from Annaji's bequest or gift deed income.

anchor.surface_text: It held that the appellant had entirely failed to prove that the money for the purchase of items 3, 4 and 5 came out of any bequest under Annajis will  Ex. B2 a   or the incomes from the properties companyered by the gift deed  Ex. D  and so in its opinion Lakshmamma companyld number claim any share in the said properties.

facts.text: Will Ex.A executed August 22, 1945, at Mandya, Lakshmamma about 64 years old, ill with paralysis.

anchor.surface_text: At the material time Lakshmamma was about 64 years of age. She usually resided at Hampapur but about a month before the executing of the will she had gone to Mandya to attend the marriage in the house of Junior Kalbagal.

facts.text: Appellant prepared draft of will day prior, dictated to scribe Chokkanna P.W.3, read to Lakshmamma, signed in 5 places, attested by P.W.1 and P.W.2, registered same day.

anchor.surface_text: So the appellant prepared a draft at Mysore a day prior to the execution of the will. He then went to Mandya by. the morning train on August 22, 1945, and the will was got written about 11 or 11-30 a.m. The appellant had the draft in his hand from which he dictated to the scribe Chokkanna  P. W. 3  who wrote the will.

facts.text: Supreme Court held will not duly executed by Lakshmamma in sound disposing state.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts then we are inclined to hold that the High Court was justified in reversing the finding of the trial companyrt oil the question of the due and valid execution of the will.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant whose sons have received the said bequests has admittedly taken a very prominent part in bringing about the execution of the will. He has prepared the draft and it was at his dictation that the scribe wrote the will.

arguments.claim: Evidence of attesting witnesses, scribe unsatisfactory; discrepancies, no clear proof of understanding contents

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of P. W. I is really inconclusive [...] The evidence of the appellant  P.W. 7  cannot obviously be useful because it is the evidence of an interested witness

arguments.claim: Previous instructions story after-thought; no corroboration

anchor.surface_text: the evidence given by the appellant on this point is clearly an after-thought and his story that he had received previous instructions cannot be accepted as true.

arguments.claim: Presumption from signature on proof; everything implied till contrary proved (citing Jarman, Williams)

arguments.court_reasoning: Applies only absent suspicions; here suspicions rebut presumption

arguments.claim: Suspicious circumstances rule applies only where propounder benefits and active; here evidence one way

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Iyengar, for the appellant, strenuously contended that, in deciding whether the suspicions attending the execution of the will have been removed or not, it would be necessary to remember that the whole of the relevant evidence is all one way

holdings.text: The will Ex. A has not been proved to be the last will and testament of Lakshmamma due to failure to prove due and valid execution.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts then we are inclined to hold that the High Court was justified in reversing the finding of the trial court on the question of the due and valid execution of the will.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suspicious circumstances (unnatural dispositions, propounder's active role and benefit, argumentative preamble, unsatisfactory witness evidence) not removed by cogent proof; onus on propounder not discharged.

holdings.text: Signatures of Lakshmamma on the will at five places (Exs. A-1 to A-5) are proved.
Lakshmamma was not proved to be in a sound and disposing state of mind at the time of execution, nor did she understand the nature and effect of the dispositions.

anchor.surface_text: that the testator at the relevant time was in a sound and disposing state of mind, that he understood the nature and effect

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence of witnesses inconclusive and discrepant; no satisfactory proof will read and understood; suspicions rebut presumption.

holdings.text: Lakshmamma did not put her signature to the will knowing its contents.

anchor.surface_text: Did he put his signature to the will knowing what it contained ? Stated broadly it is the decision of these questions which determines

holdings.reasoning_summary: No clear evidence will read fully to her and approved; scribe and witnesses' accounts inconsistent.

holdings.text: Execution surrounded by suspicious circumstances requiring propounder to discharge heavy onus by cogent evidence.

anchor.surface_text: There may, however, be cases in which the execution of the will may be surrounded by suspicious circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Shaky evidence, active propounder benefiting, unnatural bequests, artificial recitals; onus not discharged.

holdings.text: Propounder of will must prove signature (s.67 Evidence Act), execution by attesting witness (s.68), sound mind (s.59 Succession Act), understanding dispositions, free will (s.63).

anchor.surface_text: The party propounding a will or otherwise making a claim under a will is no doubt seeking to prove a document

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory requirements; prudent mind test, not mathematical certainty; heavier onus if suspicions.

holdings.text: Suspicious circumstances include shaky signature, feeble mind, unnatural dispositions, propounder active and benefiting.

anchor.surface_text: The alleged signature of the testator may be very shaky and doubtful [...] the dispositions made in the will may appear to be unnatural, improbable or unfair

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illustrative list from precedents; present here.

holdings.text: Presumption of knowledge of contents from proved signature rebutted by suspicious circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: the learned trial judge appears to have misdirected himself in law inasmuch as he thought that the proof of the signature of the testatrix on the will raised a presumption that the will had been executed by her.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial judge erred; presumption applies absent suspicions.

holdings.text: High Court not justified in obiter findings on title/subsisting interest in properties and source of purchase funds.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary once will not proved; issues left undecided.

anchor.surface_text: Harmes v. Hinkson 1  where a will is charged with suspicion, the rules enjoin a reasonable scepticism, number an obdurate persistence in disbelief. They do number demand from the judge, even in circumstances of grave suspicion, a resolute and impenetrable incredulity.

precedents.cited_proposition: When a will is charged with suspicion, the rules enjoin a reasonable scepticism, not an obdurate persistence in disbelief; judicial mind must be open though vigilant.

precedents.citation: Fulton v. Andrew 1 1875 L.R. 7 H. L- 448

anchor.surface_text: Fulton v. Andrew 1 1875 L.R. 7 H. L- 448. those who take a benefit under a will, and have been instrumental in preparing or obtaining it, have thrown upon them the onus of showing the righteousness of the transaction .

precedents.cited_proposition: Those who take benefit under a will and are instrumental in preparing it have onus to show righteousness of transaction.

anchor.surface_text: Barry v. Butlin 1 . The two rules of law set out by Baron Parke are first, that the onus probandi lies in every case upon the party propounding a will and lie must satisfy the companyscience of the companyrt that the instrument so propounded is the last will of a free and capable testator

precedents.cited_proposition: Onus on propounder to satisfy conscience of court; if propounder prepares will and benefits, suspicion arises requiring vigilant examination.

precedents.citation: Vellasawmy Servai v. Sivaraman Servai 1   1929  L.R 57 I.A. 96

anchor.surface_text: Vellasawmy Servai v. Sivaraman Servai 1 , where it was held that, where a will is propounded by the chief beneficiary under it, who has taken a leading part in giving instructions for its preparation and in procuring its execution, probate should number be granted unless the evidence removes suspicion

precedents.cited_proposition: Chief beneficiary taking leading part in preparation and execution must remove suspicion clearly proving testator approved the will.

precedents.citation: Sarat Kumari Bibi v. Sakhi Chand 2   1928  L.R. 56 I.A. 62

anchor.surface_text: Sarat Kumari Bibi v. Sakhi Chand 2 , the Privy Council made it clear that the principle which requires the propounder to remove suspicions from the mind of the Court is number companyfined only to cases where the propounder takes part in the execution of the will and receives benefit under it.

precedents.case_name: Sarat Kumari Bibi v. Sakhi Chand
precedents.cited_proposition: Principle to remove suspicions applies not only when propounder benefits but to other suspicious circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: Tyrrell v. Painton 3 . The rule in Barry v. Butlin 4 , Fulton v. Andrew 5  and Brown v. Fisher 6 , said Lindley, J., is number in my mind companyfined to the single case in which the will is prepared by or on the instructions of the person taking large benefits under it but extends to all cases in which circumstances exist which excite the suspicions of the companyrt.

precedents.cited_proposition: Suspicion rule extends to all cases exciting suspicions of the court, not just propounder benefiting.

anchor.surface_text: Brown v. Fisher 6 , said Lindley, J., is number in my mind companyfined to the single case in which the will is prepared by or on the instructions of the person taking large benefits under it but extends to all cases in which circumstances exist which excite the suspicions of the companyrt.

precedents.cited_proposition: Suspicion rule extends beyond propounder preparing will.

precedents.citation: Rash Mohini Dasi v. Umesh Chunder Biswas 7   1898  L.R. 25 I.A. 109

anchor.surface_text: Rash Mohini Dasi v. Umesh Chunder Biswas 7 it appeared that though the will was fairly simple and number very long the making of it was from first to last the doing of Khetter, the manager and trusted adviser of the alleged testator.

precedents.case_name: Rash Mohini Dasi v. Umesh Chunder Biswas
precedents.cited_proposition: Where propounder (manager) dominated execution, evidence insufficient to prove understanding.

precedents.citation: Shama Charn Kundu v. Khettromoni Dasi 1   1899  I.L.R. 27 Cal. 522

anchor.surface_text: Shama Charn Kundu v. Khettromoni Dasi 1 , on the other hand, was the case of a will the execution of which was held to be number surrounded by any suspicious circumstances.

precedents.case_name: Shama Charn Kundu v. Khettromoni Dasi
precedents.cited_proposition: No suspicion if propounder is natural beneficiary like adopted son.

precedents.citation: Bai Gungabai v. Bhugwandas Valji. 3   1905  I.L.R. 29 Bom. 530

anchor.surface_text: Bai Gungabai v. Bhugwandas Valji. 3 , the Privy Council had to deal with a will which was admitted to probate by the first companyrt, but on appeal the order was varied by excluding therefrom certain passages

precedents.cited_proposition: Onus on benefiting solicitor discharged on facts; prudent to have independent witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: Perera v. Perera 2  it was held that when the testator is of sound mind when he gives instructions for a will but at the time of signature accepts the instrument drawn in pursuance thereof without being able

precedents.cited_proposition: Sound mind at instructions suffices if testator accepts at execution remembering instructions.

anchor.surface_text: Parker v. Felgate 1  that if a person has given instructions to a solicitor to make a will and the solicitor prepares it in accordance with those instructions, all that is necessary to make it a good will if executed by the testator is that he should be able to think thus far

precedents.cited_proposition: Testator needs only recall instructions and accept faithful execution.

anchor.surface_text: Harmes v. Hinkson 1  It appears that, in this case, the testator George Harmes died in the city of Regina on April 4, 1941. Two days later Mr. Hinkson brought to the manager of the Canada Permanent Trust Company

precedents.cited_proposition: Trial judge's findings on credibility not to be disturbed lightly by appellate court.

precedents.citation: Powell v. Streatham ManoR Nursing Home 1  1935 A.C. 243

anchor.surface_text: Powell v. Streatham ManoR Nursing Home 1 . Their Lordships then referred with approval to the principles which had been frequently enunciated as to the respect which the appellate companyrt ought to pay to the opinion which a Judge who has watched and listened to the witness has formed as to their credibility

precedents.case_name: Powell v. Streatham Manor Nursing Home
precedents.cited_proposition: Appellate court respects trial judge's assessment of witness credibility.

precedents.citation: Surendra Nath Chatterji v. Jahnavi Charn Mukerji 1   1928  I.L.R., 56 Cal. 390

anchor.surface_text: Surendra Nath Chatterji v. Jahnavi Charn Mukerji 1 . In this case numberdoubt the Calcutta High Court has held that on the proof of the signature of the deceased or his acknowledgment that he has signed the will he will be presumed to have known the provisions of the instrument he has signed

precedents.case_name: Surendra Nath Chatterji v. Jahnavi Charn Mukerji
precedents.cited_proposition: Proof of signature presumes knowledge of contents, but rebuttable by suspicious circumstances.
